title: AFL trade period 2019: AFL’s most valuable asset, best young player, Marcus Bontempelli, Tim Taranto, Patrick Cripps
text:
It’s the time of the AFL year when we start looking at human beings as assets. So let’s keep doing that.

Geelong’s trade of Tim Kelly to West Coast for a haul of picks sees him valued at even more than the first pick in the draft. It’s a huge price for a young superstar.

But Tim Kelly, at 25 years old, isn’t the only great young player in the AFL. There are arguably players both greater and younger. Theoretically, they’d be worth even more in a trade.

Grand Final

Who won the Tim Kelly deal? 2:46

Inspired by that thought, we want to figure out who is the most valuable asset in the entire AFL. Or look at it this way; who would you pick first, out of the entire league, if you were starting a new club from scratch?

Let’s take context out of it. Ignore whether you’re a club in the premiership window, ignore where your club is located and if the player would want to leave, ignore contracts. Assume you’re getting the player’s entire career.

And we’re limiting this to players because while a few people might say Hawthorn coach Alastair Clarkson, we find it tough to believe one coach is more valuable than a superstar player, given how much assistants and backroom staff matter these days.

We’ve canvassed a wide range of opinions to try and answer this impossible question.

THE STATS

In this thought experiment, the age of the player is extremely important.

Because we’re saying you’re getting their entire career, even adding one or two more years of a player in their prime to a team could be the difference between winning a flag or not.

Compare Dustin Martin to Marcus Bontempelli. The Tigers star is probably a better player right now - we say probably because you can make a case for the Bulldog.

But Dusty is also five years older than the Bont. Assume they both retire at the same age - that’s five fewer years of a star player if you take Dusty. The gap between them, if it exists, isn’t worth that.

Taking this to its logical conclusion, the correct answer to the question of ‘who is the most valuable asset in the AFL’ is who best mixes talent and youth. What we want to do then is figure out which player is going to have the most value over the length of their remaining career.

Treloar was on trade table 0:31

Many global sports have popular systems for this, but one of the few for the AFL was created by the creators of HPNfooty.com, Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson.

Their system is known as PAPLEY - following in the footsteps of baseball’s PECOTA as a backronym, as in an acronym that is also a player’s name.

It uses their ‘Player Approximate Value’ system (yes, PAV) to predict the future careers of players based on their age and ability for their careers to date.

According to the PAPLEY system, the best two candidates are Bontempelli (turns 24 years old next month) and GWS’ Tim Taranto.

The latter may surprise some people, but consider that Taranto is just 21 years old (22 in January) and won the best and fairest award in a Grand Final side this year.

Tim Taranto won the Giants’ best and fairest award this season at just 21 years old. (AAP Image/Joel Carrett) Source: AAP

“At 22 next year, Taranto would be expected to play a decade or more of football. If he continues to improve on his current arc as a player, or even starts to level out, he may be (or continue being) one of the best players in the league for that time,” Atkinson told Foxfooty.com.au.

“Bontempelli will likely provide the same, just for a few years less. Bontempelli was better at age 21 (22.6 PAV v 19.3) and better this year, but with trade and list building valuations, age matters a lot, because the quantity of future career available matters.”

Systems like PAPLEY use the career paths of thousands of past players to compare current players and project their futures.

In Taranto’s case, his best comparisons for the rest of his career include superstars like Robert Harvey, Michael Voss, Mark Ricciuto and Ben Cousins.

Loose Pie steals show at B&F 1:55

“Practically every similar three-year career opening continued on to produce more future value as the average pick one,” Atkinson said.

The argument for Bontempelli as compared to Taranto is that we’ve seen the Bulldogs superstar play at this level for several years in a row.

He is a known quantity, while still having a decade of footy ahead of him. He also has the added versatility of being able to play forward.

“Bontempelli is the safer bet with more exposed form - and is also a very valid answer. If two years of good to great football isn’t enough to judge on, Bontempelli’s five years should be more than enough. Very few 21 year olds can carry teams to Grand Finals,” Atkinson said.

“Either one would be a valid choice. But Bont may simply be further along the same trajectory as Taranto is headed. Taranto is more of a risk, but his potential far exceeds anyone else in the league.”

Marcus Bontempelli has polled 19 votes or more in the Brownlow Medal in his three full seasons. (AAP Image/Michael Dodge) Source: AAP

One other contender is Patrick Cripps. He’ll be 25 next season and is viewed by many as one of the game’s best players.

But Cripps’ best skill - clearance dominance - is being less and less important. Dominant teams now score more from turnovers than stoppages.

If you built a team around Cripps, you’d be focusing on scoring from stoppages. That means you’d be off-trend in the current AFL - and as we’ve seen with Carlton, he can’t carry a team to success by himself.

Other options thrown up by PAPLEY include Brodie Grundy and Jeremy Cameron - they’re arguably the best players in their two positions right now, “but both are 25 and 26 and would waste their best remaining years on a club that would struggle in their first few seasons”.

If you like backmen, Harris Andrews has to be in the mix, while don’t count out Hawthorn’s James Worpel - “he’d be in with a shout if he had one more good year under his belt, but it’s probably too early to make that call on him yet,” Atkinson said.

For more on the PAPLEY system and other footy stats writing, head to HPNfooty.com.

Cats happy with Kelly trade 0:52

THE EXPERTS

There’s an award for the AFL’s most valuable player - it’s named as such and given out by the Players’ Association. It doesn’t quite suit this hypothetical, but it’s as close an approximation as we have.

As it turns out, the players and two Fox Footy experts were in alignment - the most valuable asset in the game is Patrick Cripps.

St Kilda champion Leigh Montagna was sure that a midfielder had to be the pick, and he was torn between Marcus Bontempelli and Cripps.

“Those midfielders that can go forward are the most valuable players in the comp. That’s why they win all the awards,” he told Foxfooty.com.au.

“It’s Bontempelli or Cripps ... Cripps. It’s a close call.”

Patrick Cripps won the AFLPA MVP award this season. (Photo by Daniel Pockett/Getty Images) Source: Getty Images

In the end Montagna opted for the Blue because of what he has been able to do in a bad team, as compared to Tim Taranto who was so impressive this year but was in a Grand Final side.

“He (Taranto) is a jet, but you can’t say he’s the most valuable player - because when you’re playing in a good team, everyone plays better. We’re all better when we’re in a good team, we’re all All-Australians and all that,” Montagna said.

“If you’re the one that’s carrying (the team), like what he (Cripps) has done at Carlton, that’s harder to do.

“Imagine if Paddy Cripps was in Geelong’s team. He would’ve won a couple of Brownlows.”

North Melbourne dual premiership player David King compared Cripps to one of his former teammates and one of the modern greats.

“I think Cripps, he’s sort of the presence that reminds me of (Wayne) Carey a bit. He’s that leader, he’s happy to have a beer with you, he trains hard, works hard, plays hard.

“I still think there’s so much scope for him ... he hasn’t hardly been forward yet. Hasn’t stepped foot inside the forward 50 yet.”

King suggested if Cripps was given “the Dustin Martin role”, he could reach heights we haven’t seen yet.

Dustin Martin might be the best player in the AFL right now, but at 28, he’s not the most valuable asset. (AAP Image/Michael Dodge) Source: AAP

THE VERDICT

If this thought experiment actually happened, there’s one factor you’d have to take into account - the human capacity for risk.

If you truly had Pick 1 in an entirety-of-the-AFL draft, you’d have a huge amount of pressure on you. Getting it wrong could ruin your club.

Because of that, you’d want to pick the best player, but also a safe option. The younger the player, the more potential years you’re getting, but the greater the risk you’re taking on.

Based on this we think the answer is Bontempelli. He has shown an ability to play at an elite level for multiple seasons in a row, for both a premiership side and a young team that needs leadership, and still has probably ten years left in him.

Could you go for Taranto, with the idea that he’ll have an extra two or three years on the back-end of his career, or Aaron Naughton, because of positional scarcity and him being even younger? Absolutely.

Could you even go for Dustin Martin or Nat Fyfe and know you have arguably the best player in the game right now? If you’re trying to win a flag immediately, they might be the better call.

But they’re not the perfect combination of youth, talent and experience that the Bont is.
